title: What happens if you don't pay an electric bill and move out? - Quora
tags: Legal Issues and Law in Everyday Life

response.answer_text: I moved into a place where the previous tenants left without paying their bill. First the electric company refused to supply service due to an overdue bill. I explained that I just moved in 12 hours ago. I insisted my family needed electricity. Next they asked for a HUGE deposit. I couldn;t figure out why I was having so much trouble after having been a home owner in the neighboring state for 15 years. They asked for my former utility company to supply a credit report which resulted in no deposit requirement. Then they tried to add the previous tenant’s bill onto mine. I told them to take it up with the landlord and provided his contact information. Same thing happened with heating oil and cable. About a year after taking up residence the water was turned off. I figured they were doing repairs and used my “emergency” water. The next day still no water. I called the township to figure out where water came from and the water company said I probably didn;t pay my bill. I asked what bill? (I had always had well water so this was a “bill” that I didn;t miss.) They got annoyed and asked for my account number. I explained I didn;t have an account. She explained it was printed on the top right of my bill. We were back to what bill? Several days later I came to find out the bill had not been paid for several YEARS and I was lucky one to live there when service was terminated. When they asked for $2500 I asked how much water cost. She told me $0.xx per unit. How much is a unit? One. Turns out they thought I used 2000 gallons of water a day for a whole year. I got the landlord to pay the bill and I contributed what I thought I owed. In short, the effects on your credit may be something you are willing to live with but tenants following you will have headaches they did not cause. You used the services. Pay your bills.

what COULD happen? jeeeze… you signed up for service with your name and details. I’ll wager you even gave them your SSN… If you were renting, your ex landlord has probably already filed suit in small claims. If you didn’t go, he got whatever he was asking for. His next step will be to locate you, give the sheriff there a copy of the judgment order and they go to pick you up and find out why you haven’t complied with that order. IF… you owned the property and defaulted they could put a lien on it…and many municipalities now put late, overdue and defaults on state tax returns (a percentage, not 100%) and collect it that way…

The very next time you tried to get electricity in the name of the person who screwed the electric company you will be not denied service no electricity for That person. Additionally when and if electricity is granted it's a privilege not a right you can always get yourself a gasoline generator fill it up with gas every 8 to 10 hours and you'll have electricity or maybe you could build a fire and do it that way but sooner or later you're going to have to have electricity and your short sighted look at the problem will cost you dearly in the future just like every time you play the victim and and in fact your the scoff law .

If you try and get power turned on in your name the power company will requie the old bill to be paid in full first, AND The amount of the old bill will now be the amount of the deposit you will have to have before they will hook you up. SO. Lets do a little math. Before you shit on your credit the deposit for power was $100.00 You walked out on a $400.00 power bill. In order to turn on power at your next apt it will cost $400.00 plus $50.00 late fees $400.00 deposit $850.00 LOL and YOU THOUGHT you were getting away with something LOL LOL SILLY BOY !!!!

The electric company will 1) report the non-payment to the credit bureaus, which will lower your credit score 2) they will sell your bill to a collection agency, further damaging your score and 3) if your next tenancy has the same electric company they likely will not turn on your service and will require a large deposit to do so. if you’re having trouble paying, call the utility and explain. If you need another 30 days or need to make payments over 2–3 months you will likely find them cooperative.

Your credit rating will be ruined. They will sell your delinquent account to bill collectors who will hunt you down and torment you for 7 years. For 7 years you will be shamed for your transgression, and if you ever accumulate wealth they will take it from you to pay your debts. As a result of your unwillingness to honor your debts, your personal character will forever be altered, you will never find a true love worthy of your attention, you will pass through this life forever dissatisfied yet never understand why.

The electric utility company will bill you anyway. If you don’t pay, they will try to collect and it will go against your credit. If you still don’t pay you will not get electrical service the next time you apply. If you pay only after a collection effort, you may get the service but be prepared to make a large security deposit of probably three times the average monthly bill for that particular dwelling (or more). If you owe it, pay it or make arrangements and get it done. It won’t go away.

If the electric bill was in your name, you will still owe it. Moving doesn't change that. And if you move to an area still covered by that same electric company, you can't establish service again until you pay what you owe. And even if you pay in full, you will now have to put down a large deposit. If you get a different electric company, they still check your credit. If they see you still owe an electric bill for another company, they are going to require a large deposit, as well.

Unless you are leaving the country, you still will have to pay this! It’s a debt owed, and will be on your credit report. There could be penalties for late payaments as well. If you think you will be able to power hooked up at a new location, you are mistaken, they do run checks on this and the new hook up will require this bill be paid before allowing you a new connection. Why not stop trying to get out of paying things you actually used and now owe, and man up (or woman up) to your responsibilites?

The utility will send you a past due notice. If you don’t respond or pay, they’ll probably assign the debt to a collection agency they contract with. Your credit record will reflect the past due bill or charge off. When attempting to get new utility service you may be required to make an otherwise unnecessary deposit prior to the start of the new services. They could take you to court, but that’s likely only if the outstanding balance is large enough to make legal action worthwhile.

First, they will still send you a bill. Secondly when you move people usually have their mail forwarded to their new address. Secondly, when you get another apartment you have to get electricity. They would ask you where you lived previously. Electric company.etc. When they find out you have an outstanding bill. They would not give you electricity without a deposit.

Years ago I bought a house. I went to move in and called the power co. to turn on electricity in my name. Seems the previous owners had skipped on the bill. The power co. would not restart elect. until bill was paid. Realtor said sorry. Cost me about a hundred dollars to get power.

The company may trace you. It is easier to find people now everything is online. Either that or they could ask your landlord, not that they are obliged to tell the electric company where you have relocated to, assuming you have told them. Social housing may share information though.

You will be required to pay it, and penalties before resuming service at a new address. If you don’t, then eventually the homeowner may have to pay it in order to restore service. Then, assuming that you ripped off your landlord in other ways and damaged their property as well, they’ll likely be highly motivated to sue you.

Well if you move to area that is still under the company your stiffed then you could be denied service until you pay the bill and then asked for a deposit but you get new service. Not sure if Power bills can go to collections, but don’t chance it and just pay the bill.

You pay it later with interest plus late fees, your credit is damaged, and your ability to get electricity in the future is lessened. The interest you pay on loans and credit cards goes up. Certain job possibilities disappear. Basically it is a very bad idea.

You won't be able to get electric in your name until that bill is paid. If it's big enough and depending where you live, your landlord can take you to court , win and attach your wages to get it paid. Don't be stupid. Pay what you can and make arrangements to continue to pay on that bill even if its a few bucks a week. You used the power. Pay for it. Responsibilty is the word of the day.

unless you move away from their billing area they will force you to pay the bill before they allow you to get your electricity turned on at your new residence.. if you move elsewhere they most likely turn your electricity bill over to a collection agency and report you to the credit bureau.
You could be sued by the landlord if there isn't enough left after repairs from the security deposit. Don't try to get electricity with that electric company anymore.
Why run the risk of messing up your credit rating? Pay the bills that you rightfully should pay. You will thank your future self when you do… it assists you in managing your finances responsibly.

Well the electric company will hunt you down and if you find a new place well as soon as you ask the electric company to open the power at your new address well will ask about the past bill and may not open the new address until you pay.
The amount of the bill will follow you to your next address.
Are you planning to move to a home without electricity? It will cost you much more to get a new hook-up than you will vbe comfortable with!
I’m not sure of the policy where you live, but where I live, there is only one electrical company and keep customer history “forever”.
The electricity will get shut off and an eviction process will start.
